The Kodinar Taluka Cooperative Banking ... vs Gujarat Information Commissioner & 4 on 24 April, 2017

Author: R.M.Chhaya

Bench: R.M.Chhaya

                 C/SCA/16441/2014                                            ORDER



                  IN THE HIGH COURT OF GUJARAT AT AHMEDABAD

                    SPECIAL CIVIL APPLICATION NO. 16441 of 2014
         ==========================================================
                THE KODINAR TALUKA COOPERATIVE BANKING UNION
                              LIMITED....Petitioner(s)
                                     Versus
             GUJARAT INFORMATION COMMISSIONER & 4....Respondent(s)
         ==========================================================
         Appearance:
         MS M O NARSINGHANI, ADVOCATE for the Petitioner(s) No. 1
         MR PRANAV S DAVE, ADVOCATE for the Respondent(s) No. 1
         MR KRUTIK PARIKH, AGP for the Respondent(s)        No. 2 to 4
         MR VIJAY H NANGESH, ADVOCATE for the Respondent(s) No. 5
         ==========================================================
          CORAM: HONOURABLE MR.JUSTICE R.M.CHHAYA

                                    Date : 24/04/2017


                                     ORAL ORDER

1. Heard Ms.Manisha O. Narsinghani, learned counsel for the petitioner - Union, Mr.Pranav S. Dave, learned counsel for respondent No.1, Mr.Krutik Parikh, learned Assistant Government Pleader for respondent Nos.2 to 4 and Mr.Vijay Nangesh, learned counsel for respondent No.5.

2. Considering the issue involved and with consent of learned counsel for the parties, the matter is taken up for its disposal.

3. By way of this petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India, the petitioner has challenged the order dated 29.09.2014 passed by respondent No.4 directing the petitioner - Union to provide information, which is sought for by respondent No.5 before respondent No.4 and by further amendment, the petitioner has also prayed for Page 1 of 6 HC-NIC Page 1 of 6 Created On Wed Aug 16 05:05:01 IST 2017 C/SCA/16441/2014 ORDER stay of the impugned order during pendency of this petition.

4. Learned counsel for the petitioner relying upon the provisions of Section 2(f) read with Section 8(1)(j) of the Right to Information Act, (hereinafter referred to as "the Act" for short), contended that the petitioner - Union is a Society registered under the Gujarat Co- Operative Societies Act, 1961 and therefore, it is public authority as defined under Section 2(h) of the Act. Relying upon the decision of the Apex Court in the case of Thalappalam Ser. Co-Op. Bank Ltd. & Ors. Vs. State of Kerala and Ors. [2013 (3) G.L.H 591], it was contended that only those information, which Registrar of cooperative societies under the Act can have access, can be made subject to the provisions of the Act. Learned counsel for the petitioner further contended that without deciding and even without giving an opportunity of hearing to the petitioner, straightway by administrative fiat, impugned order is passed. Learned counsel for the petitioner therefore, submits that present petition deserves to be allowed as prayed for.

5. Learned counsel for the respondents have supported the impugned order.

No other and further submissions are made by learned counsel for the parties.

6. Considering the submissions made by learned counsel for the parties, it is an admitted position that the petitioner - Union is registered under the Gujarat Co- Operative Societies Act and at this juncture, it would be appropriate to refer to the judgment of the Apex Court rendered in the case of Thalappalam Ser. Co-Op. Bank Ltd.

Page 2 of 6

HC-NIC Page 2 of 6 Created On Wed Aug 16 05:05:01 IST 2017 C/SCA/16441/2014 ORDER & Ors. (supra), wherein while considering the provisions of the Act, the Apex Court has observed thus:

"50. Recognizing the fact that the right to privacy is a sacrosanct facet of Article 21 of the Constitution, the legislation has put a lot of safeguards to protect the rights under Section 8(j), as already indicated. If the information sought for is personal and has no relationship with any public activity or interest or it will not sub-serve larger public interest, the public authority or the officer concerned is not legally obliged to provide those information. Reference may be made to a recent judgment of this Court in Girish Ramchandra Deshpande v. Central Information Commissioner and others (2013) 1 SCC 212, wherein this Court held that since there is no bona fide public interest in seeking information, the disclosure of said information would cause unwarranted invasion of privacy of the individual under Section 8(1)(j) of the Act. Further, if the authority finds that information sought for can be made available in the larger public interest, then the officer should record his reasons in writing before providing the information, because the person from whom information is sought for, has also a right to privacy guaranteed under Article 21 of the Constitution.
51. We have found, on facts, that the Societies, in these appeals, are not public authorities and, hence, not legally obliged to furnish any information sought for by a citizen under the RTI Act. All the same, if there is any dispute on facts as to whether a particular Society is a public authority or not, the State Information Commission can examine the same and find out whether the Society in question satisfies the test laid in this judgment. Now, the next question is whether a citizen can have access to any information of these Societies through the Registrar of Cooperative Societies, who is a public authority within the meaning of Section 2(h) of the Act.
52. Registrar of Cooperative Societies functioning under the Cooperative Societies Act is a public authority within the meaning of Section 2(h) of the Act. As a public authority, Registrar of Co- operative Societies has been conferred with lot of statutory powers under the respective Act under which he is functioning. He is also duty bound to comply with the obligations under the RTI Act and furnish information to a citizen under the RTI Act. Information which he is expected to Page 3 of 6 HC-NIC Page 3 of 6 Created On Wed Aug 16 05:05:01 IST 2017 C/SCA/16441/2014 ORDER provide is the information enumerated in Section 2(f) of the RTI Act subject to the limitations provided under Section 8 of the Act. Registrar can also, to the extent law permits, gather information from a Society, on which he has supervisory or administrative control under the Cooperative Societies Act. Consequently, apart from the information as is available to him, under Section 2(f), he can also gather those information from the Society, to the extent permitted by law. Registrar is also not obliged to disclose those information if those information fall under Section 8(1)(j) of the Act. No provision has been brought to our knowledge indicating that, under the Cooperative Societies Act, a Registrar can call for the details of the bank accounts maintained by the citizens or members in a cooperative bank. Only those information which a Registrar of Cooperative Societies can have access under the Cooperative Societies Act from a Society could be said to be the information which is "held" or "under the control of public authority". Even those information, Registrar, as already indicated, is not legally obliged to provide if those information falls under the exempted category mentioned in Section 8(j) of the Act. Apart from the Registrar of Co- operative Societies, there may be other public authorities who can access information from a Co- operative Bank of a private account maintained by a member of Society under law, in the event of which, in a given situation, the society will have to part with that information. But the demand should have statutory backing."

7. From bare reading of the impugned order dated 29.09.2014 passed by District Registrar, Cooperative Societies, District Gir-Somnath at Veraval, it clearly appears that the authority has merely acted as conduit pipe between the petitioner - Union and respondent No.5 and has just forwarded the application filed by respondent No.5 dated 01.09.2014 under the provisions of the Act, but has not examined whether the information which is sought for by respondent No.5 is within the purview and jurisdiction of respondent No.4 - Authority or not. The authority has also not come to the conclusion that whether under the provisions of the Gujarat Cooperative Societies Act, respondent No.4 being District Registrar of Page 4 of 6 HC-NIC Page 4 of 6 Created On Wed Aug 16 05:05:01 IST 2017 C/SCA/16441/2014 ORDER Cooperative Societies, has not examined whether respondent No.4 can access to the information, which is sought for in the application dated 01.09.2014 filed by respondent No.5.

8. Considering the ratio laid down by the Apex Court in the case of Thalappalam Ser. Co-Op. Bank Ltd. & Ors. (supra), respondent No.4 is duty bound to first ascertain and come to the conclusion that the information which is sought for by respondent No.5 is accessible by him as District Registrar under the Act and then can ask the petitioner - Union to provide such information. There is nothing on record to show that such exercise has been undertaken by respondent No.4. It is also a matter of record that respondent No.5 has filed an Affidavit-in- Reply and has in fact, relied upon paragraph 52 of the above referred judgment apart from denying the contentions. It is also matter of record that this Court (Coram : Hon'ble Mr.Justice N.V.Anjaria) vide order dated 16.03.2016 has passed an order in this matter to the effect that the same may be heard along with Special Civil Application No.8233 of 2014, which is also listed.

It further deserves to be noted that the said matter has been adjourned at the request of learned counsel for the petitioner in the said matter and therefore, this matter was separately heard by this court.

9. Considering the aforesaid facts of the case and considering the provisions of Section 2(h) of the Act as well as the ratio laid down by the Apex Court in the case of Thalappalam Ser. Co-Op. Bank Ltd. & Ors. (supra), impugned communication-cum-order dated 29.09.2014 issued/passed by respondent No.4 is quashed and set aside and respondent No.4 is hereby directed to decide the Page 5 of 6 HC-NIC Page 5 of 6 Created On Wed Aug 16 05:05:01 IST 2017 C/SCA/16441/2014 ORDER application dated 01.09.2014 as per the judgment of the Apex Court in the case of Thalappalam Ser. Co-Op. Bank Ltd. & Ors. (supra) and determine whether the information which is sought for by respondent No.5 is within the purview under the Act or not, and also whether in his capacity as District Registrar he has access to such information after hearing the petitioner as well as respondent No.5. Such exercise shall be undertaken as expeditiously as possible without any delay. It is clarified that respondent No.4 shall take such decision keeping in mind the ratio laid down by the Apex Court in the case of Thalappalam Ser. Co-Op. Bank Ltd. & Ors. (supra), in accordance with law, without in any manner being influenced by this order.

With the above observations and directions, the petition stands disposed of.

Direct Service is permitted.
